conclusion: Two vertical parallel metal plates are separated by distance d.
A charged small ball falls vertically (path AB) when no voltage is applied.
When voltage U is applied, the ball moves along path BC at 45°.
When no voltage is applied, only gravity acts on the ball, causing it to move vertically downward along path AB. The force is F_g = G (downward).
When voltage U is applied, there are two forces acting on the ball: Gravity F_g = G (downward) and Electric force F_e = qE (horizontal).
q is the charge of the ball (what we're solving for).
E is the electric field, given by E = U/d.
When the ball moves at 45° (along BC), the horizontal and vertical components of the net force must be equal: F_e = F_g.
Therefore, the charge amount of the small ball is q = Gd/U.
Larger weight (G) would require more charge to achieve the same deflection.
Larger plate separation (d) would require more charge (as the electric field weakens).
Higher voltage (U) would require less charge to achieve the same deflection.
